display_asset.caption: Demonstrators in Indianapolis last year after the State Legislature passed the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, which critics said could be used to discriminate against gay men and lesbians.

summaries.body: Conservatives are pushing more specific legal protections for opponents of gay rights but are meeting the same resistance that similar, but broader, legislation faced last year.

display_asset.caption: Leigh Anne Arthur, who had taught in Union County for more than a decade, in an image from a televised interview with WSPA-TV on Monday.

summaries.body: Students at a South Carolina high school have petitioned to reinstate a teacher who said she had to resign after a student took her phone and circulated a nude picture of her.

display_asset.caption: The Chinese state media has sought to humanize President Xi Jinping, also known by the nickname Xi Dada, meaning Daddy or Uncle Xi.
display_asset.credit: Pool photo by Hoang Dinh Nam

summaries.body: Seeking to show him as someone who feels deeply about family and friends, a report described a handful of known times when President Xi Jinping of China had cried.

display_asset.caption: An officer at the Atlantic Avenue-Barclays Center station. Officers citywide will use the same radio frequencies, ending the silence between those aboveground and those in the subways.
display_asset.credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times

summaries.body: A new plan calls for all New York City police officers to use the same radio frequencies, ending the silence between those aboveground and those in the subways.
The United Nations estimated that at least 9,160 people had died since the conflict in Ukraine started in April 2014.

display_asset.caption: Delmer Berg at his home in 2014.

summaries.body: Delmer Berg, the last known living veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, which vainly fought against Fascism’s advance into Spain in the 1930s, has died. He was 100.

display_asset.caption: Exiled Tibetans in Dharamsala, India, on Wednesday marching in support of two Tibetans who were said to have self-immolated in protest of Chinese rule.

summaries.body: A Tibetan monk died after setting himself on fire in Sichuan Province to protest Chinese rule, in the first known self-immolation in a Tibetan area of China since August.
Germany will continue researching the provenance of works owned by Cornelius Gurlitt, a collector whose father was a dealer for the Nazis, the culture minister said.
India’s army is cracking down on cheating on entrance exams by making candidates strip to their underwear for the test.
The director J.J. Abrams said he is taking steps to help lift diversity in movies. Speaking at a Times conference, Mr. Abrams said the work force should reflect the country.

display_asset.caption: From left, Kate Winslet, Emily Blunt and Saoirse Ronan.
display_asset.credit: From left, Jason Merritt/Getty Images; Valerie Macon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images

summaries.body: At Sunday's Oscars, many celebrities turned their backs on the lacquered look in favor of an artfully undone alternative.
Kanye West tweeted a photo of what he was listening to, but he forgot to crop out his other browser tabs, which appeared to show that he was visiting a piracy site.
Frightened by a sound near Times Square, a spooked police horse threw its rider and ran loose in Midtown Manhattan for about 10 minutes on Wednesday evening.

display_asset.caption: Tawfik Okasha taped his mouth shut in protest over not being given the floor during a parliamentary session in Cairo in January.

summaries.body: An Egyptian lawmaker chose to dine with Israel's ambassador. So Egypt’s Parliament decided to expel him. Oh, and he also was attacked with a shoe.
A new watch by TAG Heuer costs $15,950. But experts say the price might be a bargain given that the watch comes with a feature considered the holy grail for enthusiasts.
Texas Republicans are disavowing Robert Morrow, the new party chairman of Travis County. He's known for behavior that might make Donald Trump look demure.

display_asset.caption: Elliot Morales, left, and his legal adviser, Adam Freedman, on Wednesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
display_asset.credit: Louis Lanzano for The New York Times

summaries.body: A man accused of a gay-bias killing in the West Village in 2013 told a jury on Wednesday that he himself is bisexual.

display_asset.caption: Chris Rock, who hosted the 2016 Academy Awards, confronted the issue of diversity in his opening monologue.
display_asset.credit: Patrick T. Fallon for The New York Times

summaries.body: Commenting on Chris Rock's Oscars monologue on racism, Twitter users deployed #notyourmule to say it wasn't his duty to take up the struggles of every minority group.
Italian lawmakers voted to stiffen a legislative decree that olive oil producers and other critics charged would decriminalize olive oil counterfeiting.

display_asset.caption: Donald J. Trump in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday evening.

summaries.body: A revelation that Donald Trump’s family name was once Drumpf caused plenty of buzz, but the change happened long before his ancestors came to the United States.

display_asset.caption: Cycling past a newsstand outside the Beijing office of Nanfang Media Group, which owns Southern Metropolis Daily.

summaries.body: Speculation is rampant on social media in China after the publication of what some saw as a hidden message lamenting the fate of journalists on a newspaper's front page.

display_asset.caption: Smoke billowing as men pulled a tricycle in a neighborhood near a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi Province.

summaries.body: China has released data indicating that it used less coal last year than in 2014, lending support to the view that the country may be reaching a peak in coal consumption.

display_asset.caption: A Facebook innovation hub in Berlin. In an acknowledgment of the growing regulatory challenges confronting Facebook in Europe, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, traveled to Germany last month to meet with policy makers, local publishers and the company’s users.

summaries.body: Facebook became the target of a German competition inquiry on Wednesday into whether the company has abused its dominant position in social networking.

display_asset.caption: Mr. Abrams, who directed the latest “Star Wars” film, spoke at The New York Times’s New Work Summit conference about why the controversy surrounding the Oscars was a signal of the need for systemic change.
display_asset.title: J.J. Abrams on Diversity in Hollywood

summaries.body: J.J. Abrams, who directed the latest “Star Wars” film, spoke about why the controversy surrounding the Oscars was a signal of the need for systemic change.

display_asset.caption: A long-abandoned house at 745 Barbey Street in East New York, Brooklyn, where a skeletal corpse was found Monday on the second floor. The remains were discovered by the new owners.
display_asset.credit: Bryan R. Smith for The New York Times

summaries.body: The skeletal remains of a human body were found in a cluttered, abandoned house in Brooklyn. The medical examiner's office had yet to determine a cause of death.

display_asset.caption: Marvin Gaye, performing at the Royal Albert Hall in 1976.

summaries.body: Marvin Gaye, Elvis Costello and Tom Petty will be among the inductees to the Songwriters Hall of Fame at a ceremony in New York in June.

display_asset.caption: Rebecca Boenigk, the chief and a founder of Neutral Posture, a furniture manufacturer, brought in $7 million last year from government contracts and expects that to double or triple this year.
display_asset.credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times

summaries.body: The federal government has met a goal set in 1994 of awarding 5 percent of the money it spent on contractors to businesses owned by women.
An essayist describes her complex relationship with the writer James Baldwin, focusing on his experience as an African-American expatriate.
Scott Kelly has landed in Kazakhstan after 340 days in space, the longest such trip by an American astronaut. Scientists will study the health effects of his travel.
A new book proposes replacing high school algebra and calculus with statistics, arguing that the latter will be more useful in civic life.
